"But if we do open science to congressional committee review, perhaps we should also open journalism to congressional committee review?"
___________________________________

The Congress has held many hearings on publicly subsidized and financed news organs (re. NPR and VOA). The Congress has also held even more hearings on any number of publicly funded science and research projects. Why you'd want public expenditures in a singular area to be exempt from scrutiny, I fail to understand.

Do you not wish your congressional representative ensuring that your tax dollars and the nation's resources are spent wisely and appropriately?

If the people's elected representatives (in a representative democracy) are not to establish national priorities and ensure that the nation's resources are wisely spent in meeting those priorities, who would you have do it?

Nation's like North Korea, Iran, Venezuela, Zimbabwe and others do it differently. Is that the model you propose that we follow instead?

By the way, the Congress, in its infinite wisdom and liberal California representative Zoe Lofgren form, invited quasi-journalist Steven Colbert to testify in a Congressional hearing not long ago. As even a bag of rocks should know, the power of the media is infinitely greater than that of Congress, and the bags of dumb congressional rocks didn't weather that hearing storm so well.

There sure is a lot of panic and hyperbole over things that happen all the US Congressional time. I thought it was only the possibility of warm weather and longer growing seasons that panicked AGW true-believers so readily. Who knew that the requirements of the US Constitution and a representative democracy were so scary.

Since there will probably be less money for energy research, regardless of how the political winds blow in Washington, maybe we can expand usage of clean energy that we can use right now - of course, nuclear energy. This point is so obvious that the hand wringing over research money and politics seems a little silly.

I need to hear a convincing argument for not proceeding with an aggressive program to expand use of nuclear energy. Is it because its flaws are known, as opposed to the green dream of some other renewable form that has yet to be applied at scale? Nuclear is the only solution available that can approach the cost of fossil fuels. It is affordable, clean, continuous, proven.

The perfect solution hasn't been invented, and how long will it take to deploy something that is better, and after how many billions in research, assuming such billions are available?

And any other source will carry enormous political baggage. Anything as essential as energy is a political subject. You'd think that a known quantity would have an advantage. Maybe "environmentalists" will surprise us and get real about energy, but I'm not holding my breath.

The most important thing in science in general and in particular in the climate debate are the actual measurements.

Everything else, models, scientists, "consensus", opinions, take a back seat to measurements in modern science - they are comments, attempts to understand the measurements.

Before the forthcoming hearings there should be a vigorous program of publicizing the measurements through all media channels.

Climate satellites show that wit major CO2 emissions we have global cooling for 12 years, and the warming 1970-1998 was the same as the one 1910-1940 with minuscule CO2 emissions.

Sea gauges show that if anything the sea level rise rate has slowed down in the last few decades rather than increase.

Swiss records show that glaciers melt in the last few decades slower than in the 1940's.

Large sea storms are fewer and less powerful than 65 years ago.

All of this is indisputable federally measured data.

Which was not shown to the public at large, and/or covered with alarmist messages, funded by tens of billions of dollars.

Then, only after the public at large realizes the incredible size of the deception - and presumably get very very upset by it - then only should the hearings start...
Having scientific research and sustainability policies set by people who certain that social networks understand science better than scientists do...   will be interesting.  ;-)

This is rich, Andy. Hand-wringing over politicization of an issue that has become the epitome of politicization, and one that become politicized due to the acts of its practitioners, among others of course. And now that the political winds are shifting, suddenly "politics" is distasteful, something to be feared.

And is Michael Mann joking? Stunning.

And am I enjoying this turn of events? No, not particularly. I'm hoping and praying that something constructive will come out of this election. But I'm also afraid that if "climate science", as it has come to be identified as a serious subject upon which the future of the world depends, takes some serious licks from another class of politicians, then they probably have it coming.

I'm sorry but that's the way I feel.

Reversing the direction of the positive feedback loop
By Judith Curry

The positive feedback loop

I think the dynamics are much more complicated, and can only be understood by considering the ever vexatious feedback loop. There has been a particularly toxic positive feedback loop between climate science and policy and politics, whose direction has arguably been reversed as result of Climategate.

The scientists provided the initial impulse for this feedback loop back in the 1970’s and 1980’s. The enviro advocacy groups quickly saw the possibilities and ran with it, with the scientists’ blessing. The enviro advocacy groups saw the climate change issue as an opportunity to enlist scientific support for their preferred energy policy solution. Libertarian think tanks, the traditional foes of the enviro advocacy groups, began countering with doubts about the science. International efforts to deal with the climate change problem were launched in 1992 with the UNFCCC treaty.

Wait a minute, what climate change problem? In 1992, we had just completed the first IPCC assessment report, here was their conclusion: “The size of this warming is broadly consistent with predictions of climate models, but it is also of the same magnitude as natural climate variability. . . The unequivocal detection of the enhanced greenhouse effect from observations is not likely for a decade or more.”

Nevertheless, the policy cart was put before the scientific horse, justified by the precautionary principle. Once the UNFCCC treaty was a done deal, the IPCC and its scientific conclusions were set on a track to become a self fulfilling prophecy. The entire framing of the IPCC was designed around identifying sufficient evidence so that the human-induced greenhouse warming could be declared unequivocal, and so providing the rationale for developing the political will to implement and enforce carbon stabilization targets. National and international science programs were funded to support the IPCC objectives. What should have been a political debate about energy policy, environmental quality, and reducing vulnerability to weather and climate disasters, became a debate about the nuances of climate science, with climate scientists as the pawns and whipping boys.

So were the scientists innocent victims and pawns in all this? Were they just hardworking scientists doing their best to address the impossible expectations of the policy makers? Well, many of them were. However, at the heart of the IPCC is a cadre of scientists whose careers have been made by the IPCC. These scientists have used the IPCC to jump the normal meritocracy process by which scientists achieve influence over the politics of science and policy. Not only has this brought some relatively unknown, inexperienced and possibly dubious people into positions of influence, but these people become vested in protecting the IPCC, which has become central to their own career and legitimizes playing power politics with their expertise.

Andy: I am posting this after scanning about 100 comments.

I see more opportunities than problems in hearings conducted by the new Republican controlled House. I'm something of a news junkie and I see very little about warming and clean energy in the media I follow [NYT, PBS, MSNBC]. We need more. House hearings could produce news and wake up the public. If they are not treated respectfully, then the public will see that as well. If they are not allowed to make their presentations fully, then the Democratic controlled Senate can hold hearings and call these witnesses there. This will heighten the news interest and we will all gain again, except that those in charge of the House hearings will be discredited.

So bring 'em on.
